------=_Part_794350_1263237619.1428710997941
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

I am in the middle of implementing ES HyperNEAT myself in RubyNEAT, but it'=
s slow only because I actually have to hold down a day job. What would be g=
ood to have are a set of "standard problems" for HyperNEAT to solve that sh=
ows the algorithm is properly implemented.

Kind Regards,

Fred Mitchell,=
=C2=A0


+49 (0)15 259 409475, Skype: flajann
 


     On Friday, 10 April =
2015, 0:12, "Oliver Coleman oliver.coleman@... [neat]" <neat@yahoogro=
ups.com> wrote:
   

 =C2=A0   Hi Sebastian,
It was a while ago so I don't =
remember which experiments I tried, but I seem to remember having trouble e=
volving solutions for even very simple feed-forward input output mappings (=
again, I don't remember specific details). I checked and re-checked the out=
put of every stage of my implementation of ES-HN (and consulted you to clar=
ify some aspects of your implementation) but something somewhere must have =
been incorrect. I'm wondering now if the problem wasn't with the ES-HN impl=
ementation but rather that it brought out an issue with some other part of =
AHNI. I recently fixed a bug in how non-layered feed-forward networks are e=
xecuted so perhaps ES-HN was triggering this issue. If I do some more testi=
ng I'll let you know the results.
Cheers,Oliver=C2=A0

T: 0421 972 953 |=C2=
=A0E: oliver.coleman@...=C2=A0|=C2=A0W:=C2=A0http://ojcoleman.com


O=
n 31 March 2015 at 04:40, Sebastian Risi sebastian.risi@... [neat] <n=
eat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

 =C2=A0   Hi Oliver,
Yes, it's great to have c=
luster functionality in there!
Can you elaborate a little bit on what exact=
ly didn't work when you tried to run your experiments with ES-HyperNEAT? Ot=
her people might run into the sameproblems so trying to figure out exactly =
what the problem was could be helpful.
Did you ever try to implement the si=
mple maze navigation task from the same paper?
Best,Sebastian
On Wed, Mar 1=
8, 2015 at 3:59 AM, Oliver Coleman oliver.coleman@... [neat] <neat@ya=
hoogroups.com> wrote:

 =C2=A0   Hi Ken,
Yes, I've tested and verified all =
of these variants and extensions apart from ES-HyperNEAT. I've just added a=
 note to the readme about this last one:
NOTE: A lot of time was spent chec=
king every aspect of the ES-HyperNEAT implementation however it was not pos=
sible to reproduce the experiments in Risi S. and Stanley K.O. (2012) An En=
hanced Hypercube-Based Encoding for Evolving the Placement, Density and Con=
nectivity of Neurons, Artificial Life, MIT Press, thus the implementation s=
hould be assumed to be be not working. Feel free to try it out and let me k=
now how you go! :)

Cheers,Oliver

T: 0421 972 953 |=C2=A0E: oliver.coleman=
@...=C2=A0|=C2=A0W:=C2=A0http://ojcoleman.com


On 16 March 2015 at 1=
6:03, kstanley@... [neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

 =C2=A0 =
  Hi Oliver, thanks for your work on AHNI, cluster compatibility is very us=
eful.=C2=A0 As with other areas of machine learning, neuroevolution is like=
ly to benefit from massive and increasing computational power, so it's good=
 if our software can take advantage of it.=C2=A0 

By the way, I see notes =
in your github for support of all kinds of variants as well, such as ES-Hyp=
erNEAT, LEO, NSGA-II, and novelty search.=C2=A0 Are all those really workin=
g well and validated?=C2=A0 If so I'd add mention of them to my software li=
nks collection (http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software).=C2=A0 I'm also =
planning to overhaul that list because it's become so large and disorganize=
d that new people coming in can't figure out which package they should real=
ly be choosing.=C2=A0 My plan is to make it a lot more helpful in pointing =
people to what they need.=C2=A0 But anyway AHNI deserves to be featured pro=
minently.

Best,

ken=C2=A0   

   



-- 
Dr. Sebastian Risi
Assistant Pro=
fessor
IT University of Copenhagen, Room 5D10
Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 2300 C=
openhagen, Denmark
email: sebastian.risi@..., web: www.sebastianrisi.=
com

<br clear=3D"none"><span></span><div class=3D"yiv0843700404gmail_quot=

<u></u>









 
<div st=
yle=3D"background-color:#fff;">
<span> </span>


<div>
  <div>


    <=
div>
      
      
      <div>Hi Oliver, thanks for your work on AHNI, clus=
ter compatibility is very useful.  As with other areas of machine lear=
ning, neuroevolution is likely to benefit from massive and increasing compu=
tational power, so it's good if our software can take advantage of it.&nbsp=
; <br clear=3D"none"><br clear=3D"none">By the way, I see notes in your git=
hub for support of all kinds of variants as well, such as ES-HyperNEAT, LEO=
, NSGA-II, and novelty search.  Are all those really working well and =
validated?  If so I'd add mention of them to my software links collect=
ion (<a rel=3D"nofollow" shape=3D"rect" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://ww=
w.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software">http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software=
</a>).  I'm also planning to overhaul that list because it's become so=
 large and disorganized that new people coming in can't figure out which pa=
ckage they should really be choosing.  My plan is to make it a lot mor=
e helpful in pointing people to what they need.  But anyway AHNI deser=
ves to be featured prominently.<br clear=3D"none"><br clear=3D"none">Best,<=
br clear=3D"none"><br clear=3D"none">ken </div>

    </div>
     

   =
 
    <div style=3D"color:#fff;min-height:0;"></div>


</div>



  






<=
/div></div></blockquote></div><br clear=3D"none"></div>
